newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia says studying building new refinery.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia says studying building new refinery.

text.p: The Indonesian government said on Monday it was studying the possibility of state oil company Pertamina building a new refinery to meet growing domestic demand for fuel products.
"We are studying all aspects, including the possibility of Pertamina building a new refinery," director general of oil and gas Seopraptono Soelaeman told reporters.
He said the study also includes the possibility of Pertamina cooperating with the private sector in a joint venture to build the refinery.
"We are still encouraging the private sector to build refineries in Indonesia because the government has limited funds," he added.
"But depending on expensive fuel products from abroad is also dangerous," he added.
Godfried Atihuta, Pertamina's processing director, told Reuters the company has petitioned the government on the need for building new refineries.
"Indonesia needs at least two 125,000 barrel-per-day (bpd) new refineries at the moment. Domestic fuel products consumption is continuing to increase," Atihuta said.
Pertamina has said it would import about 10 million kilolitres of fuel products in fiscal 1997/98 (April-March), up from an estimated seven milion kilolitres in 1996/97.
Indonesia currently has eight refineries with a combined capacity of 989,500 bpd.
